results.headline: An Imperfect Construction
results.summary_short: In “9 Star Hotel,” the Israeli filmmaker Ido Haar draws us into the precarious world of young Palestinian construction workers scrabbling to survive.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 9 Star Hotel

results.headline: It’s Not That the Boss Seems Distant. It’s Just That He Doesn’t Exist.
results.summary_short: To describe “The Boss of It All,” Lars von Trier’s acidic corporate comedy, as “ ‘The Office’ Viewed Through the Looking Glass” only scratches the surface.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Boss of It All

results.headline: Unimpeachable Bravery
results.summary_short: “I Have Never Forgotten You” effectively sketches Simon Wiesenthal’s life, from his tenacity in surviving  genocide, to his determination to find and punish ex-Nazis after World War II.
results.display_title: I Have Never Forgotten You: The Life and Legacy of Simon Wiesenthal

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Have Never Forgotten You: The Life and Legacy of Simon Wiesenthal

results.headline: Forbidden Games: My Two Sons, My Ex-Husband, My Lover and Me
results.summary_short: “Private Property” embraces the banal and the monstrous, and affords Isabelle Huppert opportunity to astonish rather than overwhelm.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Private Property

results.headline: Closer to War
results.summary_short: “Six Days,” about the 1967 war in the Middle East, makes for an interesting compare-and-contrast exercise.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Six Days

results.headline: A Grumpy Green Giant Who Would Not Be King
results.summary_short: There is a feeling of finality about “Shrek the Third,” a sense that the tale has at last reached a state of completion.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shrek the Third

results.headline: Dead-End Jobs
results.summary_short: “Severance” turns a corporate retreat in a Hungarian forest into a bloody game of whack-a-mole. (Team building and paintballing are so last year.)

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Severance

results.headline: Memories of the ’Hood and the Mob
results.summary_short: This small, sentimental “I remember” yarn, laced with vicious jolts, is a relocated “Bronx Tale” grounded in the same old macho shtick.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Brooklyn Rules

results.headline: Reflections in Super 8
results.summary_short: While “Rolling Like a Stone” has poignant and funny moments, it’s a serious film about mortality, success and the ephemeral nature of experience and memory.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rolling Like a Stone

results.headline: A Gallery of Gamblers, Each With an Unlucky Number to Be Called
results.summary_short: “Even Money,” a scare movie about gambling addiction, is as grim and lurid as any in the recent spate of films about the evils of crystal meth.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Even Money

results.headline: The Breakdown of a Breakdown
results.summary_short: “Memories of Tomorrow” understands that the real victim of Alzheimer’s disease is the partner left behind.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Memories of Tomorrow

results.headline: A Fractured Heart and a Filthy Mouth
results.summary_short: “The Last Time” is a shapeless ode to corporate greed and business school aphorisms.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Last Time

results.headline: Battling Evildoers From Worldwide Headquarters in Woodside, Queens
results.summary_short: Too lightheaded to qualify as satire, too poker-faced to register as comedy, “Fay Grim” belongs in its own stylistic niche: the Hal Hartley film.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fay Grim

results.headline: Life That Brings Out the Beast in Humanity, and a War That’s Far From Civil
results.summary_short: Whether you like or loathe Bruno Dumont’s movies, his unsettling vision of humanity stripped of cultural finery feels profoundly truthful.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Flanders

results.headline: A Charming Slacker Fights the Power in a Retirement Home
results.summary_short: Venture capitalist: that’s the misleading job description preferred by the title character of the slight “Wendell Baker Story.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Wendell Baker Story

results.headline: War on Terror Takes a Detour
results.summary_short: With “Delta Farce,” his second movie vehicle, the Southern-fried comedian Larry the Cable Guy takes ever greater risks to advance his career.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Delta Farce

results.headline: Hey, California Girl, Don’t Mess With Grandma
results.summary_short: “Georgia Rule,” directed by Garry Marshall from a script by Mark Andrus, swerves and spins, taking its predictable plot in some surprising directions.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Georgia Rule

results.headline: Chasing an Old Flame, Taking No Prisoners
results.summary_short: The best jokes in “The Ex,” a scattershot screwball satire of job insecurity, upward mobility, political correctness and yuppie marital tensions, have claws that leave scratches.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Ex

results.headline: Realism, Both Magic and Downright Mean
results.summary_short: The characters in the western “Disappearances” speak in biblical cadences. The movie’s code, however, is the same kill-or-be-killed law of the jungle.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Disappearances

results.headline: Revisiting the True Story of a Battered Wife’s Revenge
results.summary_short: With its tone of unremitting gentility “Provoked” may be the most restrained wife-beating drama ever to grace a movie screen.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Provoked: A True Story
